moves.1. e4: This is my fourth annotation. In this annotation I would like to show you how you can come back from being the underdog near the beginning. As said in previous annotations, I always start with the king's pawn.
moves.1... e5: One of the most common defences for this move. I was actually expecting this.
moves.2. Qf3: Probably not the best option. Blocking a knight and a pawn. Attacking the black pawn on e5 would have been better.
moves.2... Nf6: Just in case I went for the early checkmate, it was blocked.
moves.3. Nc3: So my knight comes out to further defend the king's pawn.
moves.3... g6: Could have played a move that opened up the centre of the board a bit more.
moves.4. Bc4: The bishop comes out and my pieces start to take territory on the board.
moves.4... c6: A move which opens up a queen and closes off a knight.
moves.5. d3: Opening up the bishop on c1 to dominate the centre of the board.
moves.6. Bb3: The only place I could move without being taken.
moves.6... a5: About to close in my bishop. This is unstoppable, so I keep playing until he decides to attack.
moves.7. Bg5 Be7: The defence for the knight. Also defending his queen in the process.
moves.8. O-O-O: I castle queen side. Time to defend the king. Castling usually puts the king away and pretty safe if the pawns in front are there. Give the king a bit of room to move around though, otherwise if trapped, the game could be over in a few moves.
moves.8... h6: Attacks my bishop on the black square.
moves.9. Bh4: I move to still attack the knight.
moves.9... a4: If I am about to lose a bishop, I might as well take something anyway.
moves.10... Bxf6: And to no surprise, the bishop is taken.
moves.11. Nxa4: I take the pawn on a4 and in the process, losing my knight.
moves.11... bxa4 12. Bc4: I put my bishop away to safety.
moves.12... Bg5+ 13. Kb1: Not much else I could do.
moves.13... O-O: Black castles king side. White still has most control over the board.
moves.14. h4: A very not-so-smart move losing another pawn.
moves.14... Bxh4 15. g3: I go for the attack again waiting for black to retreat.
moves.15... Bg5 16. Nh3: The knight comes out to attack the bishop again.
moves.17. Ng1: A waste of a move, really, although opening the attack on h6.
moves.17... h5: Of course, black sees this and blocks the h-file attack.
moves.18. g4: Still trying to attack on the side.
moves.18... Ba6: Didn't expect that. But then again, what was black meant to do?
moves.19. Qe3: The queen moves to attack the h-file. If the pawn on h5 is removed, the path to checkmate is near.
moves.19... Bg5: The bishop comes to attack my queen. Time to try another attack.
moves.21... c5: Opening the knight in black's defensive line.
moves.22. gxh5: Time to deliver the h-file attack.
moves.24. Rd6 Rh8: Blocked, forking my rook on the other end. Unless...
moves.25... Qe7: My rook is under attack from the queen. Black has taken domination of the board.
moves.26. Rxh8: Exchanging rooks in the back corner of the h-file.
moves.26... Kxh8 27. Qh5+: Giving my rook more time to get out of there.
moves.27... Kg7 28. Rd3: Really the only way to save my rook was to move it out.
moves.29. Nh3: If I can get that bishop out of the way, I might be able to finish black.
moves.29... Bh6: Defending the king, ensuring not to lose the game.
moves.30... Kf8 31. a3: Opening up the king for a not-so-nice attack from black.
moves.31... Nc6: Knight comes out from the defensive line.
moves.32. c3: Maybe opening up the king a little too much.
moves.32... Ke7: Black gets his king out of the black line to give the rook a bit more space at the back.
moves.33. f3: Just making sure the pawn won't get taken.
moves.34. Ng5: The knight comes in hoping the bishop would move away and get taken by the rook.
moves.35... Rh8: The rook is planning to get my king on the defensive line.
moves.36... Kd8: He moves back. Maybe Kd6 would have been better in winning the rook.
moves.37. Qg5: Had to get the queen away.
moves.37... Qxg5: We exchange queens which is not so good for me as even though we are close on points, I'm running out of pieces to work with.
moves.38. Rxg5 Nxc4: Black takes my pawns one by one.
moves.39. Rxc5: We both try to win each other's pawns.
moves.39... Nd2+: And also to get the other player into a bad position. topknot33 tries to corner my king and blocking off my openings.
moves.40. Ka2: Maybe Kc2 would have been better.
moves.40... Nxf3: Slowly losing my pawns. Maybe Rh1 would have almost finished it.
moves.41. Ra5: Trying to fork the rook on the other side of the king.
moves.42... Ke7 43. Rxh8: If I capture the knight, maybe I could win.
moves.43... Nxe4 44. Rh4: Hoping the knight wouldn't move to Nc5.
moves.44... Nc5: I knew it. Black obviously wouldn't give up a pawn. Why would he anyway?
moves.45. b4: Hoping that black wouldn't pull of the en passant. See how much luck I'm depending on?
moves.45... Nb3: The en passant would have worked better and the promotion of a queen would have come up quick.
moves.46. b5: I try promote my own pawns, and also attacking a4.
moves.46... Kd8: Winning a pawn at this time of the game is pretty good. Black is running out of checkmate options, and is a few points down (which is not that bad).
moves.47. Rxa4: I win the pawn. This game has turned dramatically after losing by the same amount of points (please see the_golfer vs obee_ton as I prove that being ahead doesn't really matter in the end).
moves.47... Nc5: Not unexpected for black. What else was there to do? Maybe Nc1 though...
moves.48. Ra7: Trying to promote my pawn would definitely win the match.
moves.48... Kc8: The king comes in. At this stage, the king is vital in achieving checkmate.
moves.49. Ra5 Kb7: The king closes in on winning the rook or pawn.
moves.50... f5: Better be careful now. The f-file pawn is free and is soon going to turn into a queen.
moves.51. Kb2: I try to stop it with my king. I will get there first even though we are going at the same slow pace.
moves.55. Ra6: The rook moves up on the a-file attempting to promote a pawn.
moves.55... Nd2: Nd2 allows me to take the almost promoted pawn, but lose c4.
moves.57... Na3: Comes in for an attack on the pawns.
moves.58... Nc4: Decides not to go with it.
moves.59. Kf3: If I lost my pieces, I would need to get my king into the action.
moves.59... d6: A slow way to get a pawn promoted on the d-file.
moves.61. Kd5: What will black pull off now?
moves.61... Na3: The knight is back where it moved four moves ago. A waste of moves?
moves.62... Kd7: The king would have been better of Kb7 although I would have responded Ra7+.
moves.63. b7: The pawn is on the last line.
moves.63... Kc7: Of course black would do that.
moves.64. Rxd6: Ra7 would have been better there.
moves.64... Kxb7: Losing a pawn. Made some bad decisions here.
moves.65. a6+: The king is running out of options.
moves.65... Ka7: Annoying, as I don't have much to work with anymore.
moves.66. Ke6: So I try to close the king in with my own king. Expecting the knight to move now.
moves.66... Nc4: Nice move. If black clears the pawn, the white king is free.
moves.67. Rc6: Is black going to finally retreat?
moves.67... Nb6: Here comes the interesting part of the game.
moves.68. Kd6: Probably the best move I could pull.
moves.68... Kxa6: The knight is now forked to the king. Time to take it.
moves.69. Kc5 Kb7 70. Rxb6+: Success. The game has turned unexpectedly for me.
moves.70... Kc7: Now to trap the king in the a-file corner.
moves.71. Rd6 Kb7 72. Rc6 Kb8 73. Kb6 Ka8: The last legal move and the last move for black.
moves.74. Rc8#: The game ends in a win for me, although I played a lot of silly moves, I could still come out to win. I would like to thank topknot33 for the game. It was great to play with you. Thanks also to blake84120.
